docs.snippet: The new Where the Wild Things Are game works on only one level: that of the bored elementary or middle school student killing a few hours before dinner.
docs.lead_paragraph: It is often said of good family films that they work on multiple levels: they entertain both adults and children. Creating a tale of multigenerational appeal usually entails combining the exaggerated, less subtle visual vernacular of youngsters with writing laden with meaning for their parents. That could have been the case with the new Where the Wild Things Are game. But it isn't. The Wild Things game works, serviceably, on only one level: that of the bored elementary or middle school student killing a few hours before dinner.

docs.snippet: A battle over which casino gets to introduce a popular new slot machine has spilled over into court, with two casinos suing another -- as well as the game's maker.    The dispute centers on Triple Play Poker Joker, a video poker game that made its...
docs.lead_paragraph: A battle over which casino gets to introduce a popular new slot machine has spilled over into court, with two casinos suing another -- as well as the game's maker. The dispute centers on Triple Play Poker Joker, a video poker game that made its Atlantic City debut on Wednesday at Harrah's Casino Hotel.
docs.abstract: Battle over which casino gets to introduce popular new slot machine spills over into court, with two casinos suing each other--as well as game's maker; dispute centers on Triple Play Poker Joker, video poker game that makes its Atlantic City debut at Harrah's Casino Hotel; same day, Bally's Park pLace and Atlantic City Hilton file suit, calling Harrah's agreement with machine's maker, International Game Technology, illegal and unfair because it only allows Harrah's to offer game (S)

docs.abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Fair Game column observes that clawbacks, or compensation returned to by an employee found to have committed financial improprieties, are gaining support among investors and companies--though examples are rare; wonders how many years it will be before firms put clawback provisions into effect.

docs.snippet: LEAD: The blackjack tables, the roulette wheels and the dice are still there. But the companies that make gambling equipment have turned the casinos into high-technology arcades. Rows of electronically linked slot machines monitor wagering, accept...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The blackjack tables, the roulette wheels and the dice are still there. But the companies that make gambling equipment have turned the casinos into high-technology arcades. Rows of electronically linked slot machines monitor wagering, accept hundred-dollar bets or deliver million-dollar, lottery-style jackpots.

headline.main: All About/Gambling Equipment;   Hardware Makers Cash In On America's Betting Mania

docs.snippet: If you have been to an arcade lately, you may have noticed an unusual type of batting cage, where would-be sluggers swing at the air as their fantasy hits are depicted on a screen. Parents beware: the technology is coming home.
docs.lead_paragraph: If you have been to an arcade lately, you may have noticed an unusual type of batting cage, where would-be sluggers swing at the air as their fantasy hits are depicted on a screen. Parents beware: the technology is coming home. XaviX, a Japanese company, is selling a game system that integrates wireless motion-recognition technology into tennis, baseball and bowling video games. The XaviX Port, available at amazon.com for $80, works with three peripheral devices that must be purchased separately: a tennis racket, a bowling ball or a baseball bat, each of which costs $50.The Port, which connects to any television by infrared or standard audio-video cables, senses velocity as the player swings in front of the set. The players' movements are reproduced on the television screen.
docs.abstract: Port video game console from XaviX incorporates wireless motion-recognition technology into sports video games; photo (S)

headline.main: Take a Swing for the Fences (Careful You Don't Hit the TV)

docs.snippet: In and around San Jose, Calif., electronics companies fire off declarations of war, challenging each other up and down Silicon Valley. But this time the stakes are not millions of dollars in computer business, but flags. The contest is the National...
docs.lead_paragraph: In and around San Jose, Calif., electronics companies fire off declarations of war, challenging each other up and down Silicon Valley. But this time the stakes are not millions of dollars in computer business, but flags. The contest is the National Survival Game, a pastime that the manual describes as an adult version of capture-the-flag, but which has more than a passing resemblance to cowboys-and-Indians. The game is now played by thousands of grownups from San Jose to the Florida palms to Coram, L.I. It is also being attacked by at least one psychiatrist as creating a climate of acceptance for violence.
